author: jtraglia
content: Hey <@219015859182632960>, now that we've decided to include cell KZG proofs in the blob transaction, I don't believe there will be much of a difference compared to now. Cell KZG proof verification is very fast, just like blob KZG proof verification. The extra CPU usage will fall on L2s who submit blobs. There might be extra CPU usage for validators with a lot of staked ETH, who will be required to custody lots of data columns. They may be asked to recompute/gossip all of the proofs if there's missing data/proofs. But with proofs in the transaction, I'm not totally sure how this works. <@520034910149410861> would know more about that part.

author: yorickdowne
content: Oh amazing thank you. So we're saying, as of now, subject to change, 4 cores/8 threads and 32 GiB RAM will handle PeerDAS just fine. That kind of machine is between 10-20% CPU utilization right now.

author: yorickdowne
content: Which, and this is my very personal interpretation, means that the new foundation recommendation of 8 cores/16 threads and 64 GiB RAM is there to not lock Ethereum into any one particular path: That kind of machine will handle whatever the protocol does in the next few years

author: yorickdowne
content: But stakers can reasonably build as they have been, and react by replacing their node, if they need to in future.
